key_points: Ransomware attacks in the US are becoming more frequent and sophisticated, mostly conducted by Russia-based hackers.
Targets have included solar power firms, government agencies, water treatment plants, police departments, and now the Colonial Pipeline.
The Colonial Pipeline, carrying 45% of the East Coast's fuel, was shut down due to a ransomware attack, causing fuel shortages and price hikes.
Colonial Pipeline reportedly paid a $5 million ransom fee and initiated the restart of operations.
Cybercriminal group Darkside has taken responsibility for the attack, indicating a shift towards targeting larger organizations.
The number of ransomware attacks on government agencies and private companies is rising, with many opting to pay the ransom.
The shift from ransom to extortion tactics signifies the evolution of cybercriminal methods, with data encryption and exfiltration.
Cybercriminals are also selling ransomware software on the dark web, increasing the potential for more attacks.
The FBI and security experts identify Darkside as a criminal group based in Russia, but Joe Biden stated there is no evidence linking the Russian government to the attack.
Experts believe the recent surge in ransomware attacks, including the one on Colonial Pipeline, could be a form of marketing by cybercriminals.
spokespersons: Eric Cole (author of Cyber Crisis and founder, Secure Anchor)
